content: The Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA), 18 U.S.C. 1030, protects federal interest computers from trespassing, threats, damage, espionage, and fraud. It complements other state and federal criminal laws and has been amended over the last three decades. CFAA focuses on computers as victims, while other laws address computers in different contexts such as crime arenas or evidence repositories. The Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA), 18 U.S.C. 1030, outlines various offenses related to computer trespassing, fraud, threats, and espionage. It prohibits actions such as damaging government or bank computers, unauthorized access to sensitive information, and trafficking in passwords. Attempting or conspiring to commit these offenses is also considered a crime under the Act. Penalties for these offenses are detailed in subsection 1030(c). The Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA), 18 U.S.C. 1030, outlines various offenses related to computer trespassing, fraud, threats, and espionage. It prohibits actions such as damaging government or bank computers, unauthorized access to sensitive information, and trafficking in passwords. Penalties for these offenses are detailed in subsection 1030(c). Subsection 1030(b) makes it a crime to attempt or conspire to commit any of these offenses, with penalties ranging from imprisonment for not more than a year to life imprisonment for death-result offenses. Subsection 1030 fraudulently preserves the investigative authority of the Secret Service, while subsection 1030(e) provides common definitions. Subsection 1030(f) disclaims any application to otherwise permissible law enforcement activities. Subsection 1030(g) creates a cause of action for victims of these crimes. Subsection 1030(h) called for annual reports through 1999 from the Attorney General and Secretary of the Treasury on investigations under the damage paragraph (18 U.S.C. 1030(a)(5)). Subsections 1030(i) and (j) authorize the confiscation of property generated by, or used to facilitate the commission of, one of the offenses under subsection 1030(a) or (b). (a) Whoever ... (3) intentionally, without authorization to access any nonpublic computer of a department or agency of the. Paragraph 1030(a)(3) of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act prohibits unauthorized intrusion into federal government computers, whether exclusively used by the government or shared with others. Attempted intrusions and conspiracies to intrude are also outlawed under subsection 1030(b). Unauthorized access to shared computers is only considered a crime if it affects the government's use or would have affected it if the attempt had been successful. Unauthorized access to government computers is prohibited under the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act, whether the computer is exclusively used by the government or shared with others. Intrusions, attempted intrusions, and conspiracies to intrude are all outlawed. Unauthorized access to shared computers is only considered a crime if it affects the government's use. The Committee clarifies that the new subsection will only ban intentional trespassing on Federal computers, without the need to show further actions on the accessed information. It aims to cover individuals without authorized access, including those who maintain access after an inadvertent initial entry. Congress allows for a certain level of trespassing by government employees to protect whistleblowers, and the Committee is specific about who can be prosecuted under the new subsection. The Committee aims to balance the protection of Government computers against abuse by "outsiders" while allowing a certain degree of trespassing by government employees to protect whistleblowers. They clarify who may be prosecuted under the new subsection and do not criminalize acts where an employee exceeds authorized access in their own department. The Committee believes that administrative sanctions are more appropriate than criminal punishment for unauthorized access within a department. They distinguish between unauthorized access within a department and trespasses into computers of another department to prevent prosecution for minor infractions. The Committee has limited 18 U.S.C. 1030(a)(3) to cases where the offender is completely outside the Government or where the offender's act of trespass is interdepartmental in nature, to prevent prosecution for minor infractions within a department. The Committee limits 18 U.S.C. 1030(a)(3) to cases of trespass involving interdepartmental acts to prevent prosecution for minor infractions within a department. Trespassing on governmental computer space is prohibited only when it affects government use or use for governmental purposes. Serious intradepartmental trespass cases may be subject to other criminal penalties under proposed legislation. The trespassing ban on computer space not exclusively for governmental use is prohibited only when it affects government use or use for governmental purposes. The Department of Justice has concerns about the language of the subsection and clarifications have been made to specify that the offender's conduct only needs to affect the use of the government's operation of the computer in question. The reports do not provide much insight into which computers are protected from trespassing. The statute 1030(a)(3) protects government computers from trespassing, with specific language indicating that it applies to computers owned or leased by the federal government. It also covers government computers available for non-governmental use. The statute 1030(a)(3) protects government computers from trespassing, including those owned or leased by the federal government and available for non-governmental use. The term "nonpublic" clarifies that shared access does not extend to the general public. Definitions for "department of the United States" and "agency of the United States" are provided in the section. The jurisdictional aspect of paragraph 1030(a)(3) remains unclear. The jurisdictional aspect of paragraph 1030(a)(3) is unclear, particularly regarding hacking initiated or occurring overseas. Federal laws generally apply within the United States, but exceptions exist when Congress explicitly negates the presumption or when the nature of the offense suggests overseas application. In the cybercrime context, courts have ruled on the extraterritorial reach of certain federal statutes. The federal statute outlawing conspiracy to violate federal law applies to overseas smuggling conspiracies. In cybercrime, courts have ruled that unauthorized computer access to defraud applies to hackers overseas. Congress amended the definition of "protected computers" to include those used in foreign commerce. Extraterritorial jurisdiction was explicitly provided for computer-related offenses, but not for simple trafficking offenses. The amendment to the federal statute includes provisions for computer-related offenses such as fraud, damage, and extortion, with penalties for violations including imprisonment and fines. Extraterritorial jurisdiction is granted for certain offenses under specific paragraphs, while simple trafficking offenses may not fall under this jurisdiction. Other consequences for offenses include forfeiture, restitution, racketeering, and civil liability provisions. The forfeiture provisions of subsections 1030(i) and (j) authorize the confiscation of a cyber trespasser's computer and property. Federal authorities historically did not prosecute juvenile offenders, but most federal crimes, including computer hacking, are crimes under state laws. Juveniles violating federal law may be turned over to state authorities unless certain conditions are met. Paragraph 1030(a)(3) has seen few prosecutions since 1986, possibly due to its similarity to paragraph 1030(a)(2). Subsection 1030(b) punishes attempts to violate any paragraphs of subsection 1030(a), with no general federal attempt statute existing. The law surrounding attempts to violate federal computer laws requires proof of intent and a substantial step towards the offense. Conspiracy to access a government computer without authorization is a separate federal crime, with all involved parties being guilty regardless of success. If a conspirator successfully hacks into a government computer, all involved can be prosecuted under paragraph 1030(a)(3). Conspiracy to access a government computer without authorization is a federal crime, punishable under subsection 1030(b) with specific penalties outlined in subsection (c). Conspiracy to commit federal misdemeanors under subsection 1030(b) may result in penalties equal to the underlying misdemeanor. Those who aid or abet federal crimes are liable as principals for the offense. Subsection 1030(b) also addresses attempts to violate subsection 1030(a), raising questions about accessories in criminal liability. The liability of accessories in criminal offenses under subsection 1030(a) raises questions, particularly in cases of aiding or abetting a crime that never goes beyond the attempt phase. Computer trespassing, such as hacking into government computers without causing damage, is a unique offense with limited overlap with other laws. The terms "without authorization" and "exceeds authorized access" have posed challenges in court interpretations. The courts have faced challenges in interpreting the terms "without authorization" and "exceeds authorized access" in paragraph 1030(a)(2) of 18 U.S.C. 1030. Some courts have applied these terms to unauthorized use by authorized employees or outsiders with access subject to restrictions. Others have distinguished between accessing a computer without any permission and accessing information not entitled to. Paragraph 1030(a)(2) covers a wider range of computers and information, including federal government, financial, and protected computer information. The protection for financial information under 18 U.S.C. 1030(a)(2) aims to safeguard computerized credit records and information related to customers' relationships with financial institutions. The legislation intends to extend privacy protections to all customers of financial institutions, not just individuals or partnerships with five or fewer partners. The Department of Justice has raised concerns about the broad scope of the term "obtains information" in this subsection. The Department of Justice has concerns about the term 'obtains information' in 18 U.S.C. 1030(a)(2) potentially requiring proof of data asportation. The committee clarified that 'obtaining information' includes mere observation and does not necessitate physical removal or copying of data. This interpretation extends to information obtained from federal computers and through cyberspace trespassing. The term 'obtaining information' in the Computer Fraud and Abuse statute includes merely reading it, without the need for copying or transporting it. This interpretation aims to prevent the theft of intangible information stored electronically, ensuring that unauthorized use of a computer to steal such information is prohibited. This subsection also addresses the theft of copyrighted information, potentially implicating rights under copyright laws. The Identity Theft Enforcement and Restitution Act of 2008 expanded the reach of computer theft laws by eliminating the requirement for interstate communication and broadening the definition of a "protected computer" to include those affecting interstate commerce. This allows authorities to address hacking crimes within the same state and extends coverage to any computer with even a minimal impact on commerce. The amendment also considers computers accessing the Internet as being used in interstate commerce. No need to prove violation of paragraph 1030(a)(5) as long as this type of loss or damage has been suffered.
